title: Questor share tip: Questor's worst share tip makes progress
text:
5.51 0.00 
Questor was horribly early recommending shares in Balfour Beatty (Other OTC: BAFBF - news ) , but if anything it provides a perfect example of how underlying value can protect from profit warnings, dividend cuts and management exodus 
Balfour Beatty 261.6p+9.9p Questor says HOLD 
Balfour Beatty [LON:BBY] has something of a problem. While it would like to draw a line under loss-making contracts and reassure investors that the turnaround is on track, in the notoriously tricky world of construction it simply can’t offer those assurances. 
= Construction crunch = 
Planning the cost of building projects is always, excuse the pun, difficult to nail down. From the home kitchen extension to the multi-billion-pound national infrastructure project, there is always an element of finger in the air when working out how much the materials, manpower and expertise will cost. 
When times are good, this isn’t so much of a problem. As big construction projects overrun, customers are willing to discuss how they can be funded. In an environment of strained finances, these discussions are often much shorter. 
In an effort to win work in the competitive heat of the financial crisis six years ago, Balfour is now paying the price of rising building material costs and wages. 
= Construction crunch = 
Balfour Beatty has become something of a poster child for the sector’s woes. The previous management team has been culled following a string of profit warnings , Balfour was nearly taken over by rival Carillion (Other OTC: CIOIF - news ) last year and the dividend was axed in March this year . 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) chief executive Leo Quinn, former boss of Qinetiq, unveiled a first-half loss of £152m to June 26, as he attempts to puts his own estimate on the profitability of the projects. 
Balfour Beatty chief executive Leo Quinn joined the company in January 
Mr Quinn said that 90pc of the old problem contracts should be finished by the end of next year. Unfortunately that still leaves 14 months for things to get worse. The company will have built some fat into the provisions on each contract, but investors are still exposed to the vagaries of a tough UK market. 
The Far East may also hold surprises. In particular the Hong Kong Express Rail Link is a headache. Balfour is in discussions with the customer, but if those talks end badly then there will be more pain to come at the year end. 
= Reasons to believe = 
Balfour has plenty of qualities to ride out the storm. Under Mr Quinn a focus on cash led to an inflow of £362m in the first half, leaving a £260m cash pile on the balance sheet at June 26. The business is focusing on cutting costs and made £25m in savings during the first six months with a total target of £100m by the end of next year. 
The builder is also sitting on an attractive investment portfolio of infrastructure assets worth £1.25bn, for which there is no shortage of demand as they generate inflation linked income. The value in that portfolio of assets underpins the shares as the whole company is worth £1.8bn 
Mr Quinn is tentatively optimistic on the outlook. There are some big projects on the horizon such as HS2, British nuclear and tenders for a potential new runway at Heathrow. The order book is stable, down slightly from £10.4bn to £10.3bn at the end of June. 
Investors gave Mr Quinn the benefit of the doubt and the shares jumped more than 4pc higher to 263p yesterday, bringing gains so far this year to 24pc. 
Balfour Beatty has been one of Questor’s worst share tips, having r ecommended them at 273p in October 2013 and again at 293.5p January 2014 , on early signs of a recovery it has been a rollercoaster ride. We’ve learnt our lesson and until trading is solidly profitable and dividends return it remains a hold.
